Felly, ydych chi'n dweud y byddai'n gweithio'n dda i chi'r ffactor?
O, i.
Why do you think that was?
Well, I'd like to think it was because they wanted someone in Cardiff to be in the Olympic Games.
But I can't really say I know.
It might just have been jobs for the boys because this gentleman that had made the request
for them to find me a job, I mean, I don't know what contacts he had with the company
or with whom within the company either.
So I don't know.
But yes, they were supportive.
And then if I needed extra time off for training, you know, sometimes it was a training away
and you'd travel up on a Friday, they were quite happy for me to go.
So they were very good, very good.
British Small Arms, BSA was for, British Small Arms, it was the full name of the company.
British Forlamp Tools, BSA Tools.
So, and what was your exact work then?
Did you say clarking?
Yes, clarking. Clarking, that was all.
I used to have to walk down the factory with the steel stores if it looked as if they were running out of something
and then the men used to whistle in time with my feet all the way down, you know, to torment me.
But yes, it was just really, I suppose it was quite responsible in a way
because I had to make sure that all the materials and there were so many different metals and things
that were required for the various jobs that they were always stocked there.
Not that I ordered the stock, I would pass on the need and someone else would do the ordering.
So I suppose it was quite responsible really.
And I was the only one doing it, so, you know, I was making sure, well, giving them the notes
in order to acquire the metals they needed for every job that was going on in the factory.
So I suppose it was quite responsible.
I can't say I felt great weight of responsibility at the time, but when I think of it now,
I mean, if they'd have had the wrong metal for a start, I'd have been up the road in no time.
I thought you were going to say in for the high jump.
Yes, that would have been a good thing for me, yes.
How did you feel about the man's behaviour?
Did you find it threatening?
No, no, it was all in good fun.
They usually used to whistle in time in my feet, you know, and however I changed my walk,
they would adjust the rhythm and they would call out to me, you know,
are you coming out with me tonight and things like that.
But there was never anything offensive or abusive and I never felt threatened.
And there was nothing physical?
No, no, no. They were very protective of me actually.
I think perhaps because I was little and young, they were very protective.
Maybe some of the older girls had a bit more epinomy anyway.
That was the Charlie Chaplin tune, was it?
Yes.
I had to dee da dee da as I went down.
What about, were there other local people working in the factory that?
Yes, I think a lot of the people that worked there were local.
But of course some of the skills were quite acute because they used to make instruments,
surgical instruments and things like that.
So although I'm quite sure part of their work was large scale work,
when it came to the intricate making of things,
they could quite possibly have been shipping specialists for that.
I really wouldn't know.
Most of the office for that factory were upstairs except mine.
Well, I wasn't the only one in it, but the office I was in was the only one
that was actually on a factory floor for convenience, for its purpose.
I don't think the others came in contact with the men much at all.
There were no women working in a factory at all.
On the floor?
On the floor, none.
What about women in the office? Were there women in the office?
Yes, there were women there as well doing various jobs to do with orders and things like that,
things that were coming in that needed to be done.
Mine was just a small part of that, just making sure the materials were there for them
and that they could access them when they needed.
There was a...what do you call it?
Down the end, like a big forge where they melted stuff and they can't remember the name of that big one.
Furnace?
Furnace. There was a big furnace down the end.
Down the end. The man fell in, actually, the molten liquid, molten metal while I was there.
Didn't find any of him at all. Just disappeared.
Oh.
But I wasn't a witness to that.
No. Can you remember your first day at work and what your impressions were of...
What, the first day in BSA?
In BSA, yes.
I was very nervous because I didn't know anything about the company
or anything about what I was going to have to be doing.
So I suppose I was nervous in a way, but there was a lady who had been doing that job for some time
that was retiring and she was very good. She sort of helped me get to grips with it before she left.
So they gave me an opportunity for some training with her before I was left on my own to deal with it.
But no, it wasn't a comfortable office because it was on the factory floors.
It wasn't carpeted or, you know, it was a bit dirty at times because there was a lot of metal dust
and so it would come up because it didn't have a lid on our office if you wound up to the roof.
But no, I was quite happy there.
How long did the training go on for?
Oh, just about three weeks, I think. That was about it.
And then of course there was a scene that the manager of that particular department was in a side office half hours.
So if I'd have had any trouble I could have sought help there, I'm sure.
But I can't remember needing to do it. It wasn't a difficult job.
But do you feel that you were well trained by then?
Not really because the lady who did it with me, she made sure that I understood it all.
But nobody checked after that, it was okay.
So we looked at it like that way.
There was no... I suppose you could say they were trusting.
How were the physical appearance of the building?
You've told me how you felt, but when you walked in there, what was it?
Can you describe it?
Oh yes, it was quite dismal.
It was like a corrugated building really with some concrete walls and things.
It was an old munitions factory and they threw them up in the wall because of the need.
So there weren't any finer points to it.
The girls in the office upstairs had more amenable surroundings.
But I can't say I ever felt that we were neglected in any way.
There was a canteen there that catered for us very well.
Otherwise to go home for lunch on my bike.
But yes, it was a typical dusty, noisy factory.
It was noisy, was it?
Yes, some parts of it were noisy.
The end where they made the fine instruments was at our end and that was quiet.
But as you went down, it got noisy.
What about the smell? What did it smell of?
It smelled dreadful when I first went there, but I got used to it then.
I've had a phone and didn't smell it at all then.
So yes, it was just an oily, engineering-type smell.
Nothing really offensive.
When I first went there, I wasn't too keen, but as I say, I got used to it.
It didn't matter.
What did the women in the offices upstairs do then?
They did all sorts of paperwork.
There was a drawing office there because they were designing things,
designing equipment and implements and so on.
There were mostly men up there in the drawing office,
but there were some women there as well,
and clerical workers and secretaries and so on.
To be honest, we didn't have any reason not to,
but we didn't have a great deal to do with them.
We could see them in the county, but when we went,
there were four men and three women in that county myself where I was.
So when we went for our break, we three were always together on the table talking.
We'd speak to the others, but we didn't really have a lot to do with them.
Were the drafts women there as well?
I think there was one. The rest were all men.
I think the woman was only really there because there was no photocopy.
They had a machine that turned around the ink.
I forget what they called that.
It was like a sort of copy machine.
The lady that was there did a bit of drawing,
but to be honest, I think she did most of that sort of thing.
Can you remember how much you were paid?
No, I can't. It was only just a few pounds. It wasn't a lot.
How did it seem to you at that age though?
It was more than I was getting in boot to the chemist,
so I was quite pleased about that.
But it really was just juniors rate.
I think I was only considered to be a junior,
although when I look back on it now, it was a fairly responsible job to get it right.
So what did you do with your money?
I lived at home.
My mother used to put my money aside for me so that I could get the train
towards my training and things.
As I say, when I went to the games, there was a great list of things to buy.
It was an expensive business.
If you had to get there on your own, it was your train fare.
My mum would never let me go if I needed a new coat until I had a new coat,
that sort of thing.
Then there was always a gift for the lady you'd be staying with,
because someone would put you up there.
My mother would cry because she had to part with her tea coupon
and I didn't drink tea.
But as far as the money was concerned, it sort of went in this pot.
My parents didn't have any of it.
They just used it as part of the support that I needed,
and it was only a small part of the support I needed.
I was going to ask, were there any unions in the factory?
Were you aware of anything?
I wasn't aware of it.
There must have been for the men, I would think,
because they had several professions there.
So they must have been for the men.
But I was certainly not asked to join a union.
So you weren't in a union?
I wasn't in a union.
And you weren't aware of an office union, were you?
No.
Did you feel that you were fairly treated?
Yes, I was quite happy there.
Do you feel that everybody was fairly treated?
Yes, the ones that I knew.
I didn't hear no one complain.
I can't see much about the men in the factory,
because I really wouldn't know anything about them.
But in our office, everyone seemed to be okay.
Were you aware of any disputes, though?
No, never.
I was there until I was 19.
During that time, I wasn't aware of any.
I did have a good deal of help on one occasion,
because I used to ride a bike to work,
and we had a terrible snowstorm.
When I was in school, I never missed a half-day school,
all my education.
My parents, my mother, would say,
you'll feel better by the time you get there.
I never even lost a half-day in the whole of my schooling.
I think that stayed with me.
It helped me with my gymnastics and with the rest of my future.
It taught me commitment.
So the snow came pouring down, and I got on my bike to go.
As I turned a corner, I lived in Grangetown.
It was a Grange garden, it says to cycle past.
As I turned the corner, so this great lot of snow flew in my face.
I put my head down and went into the back of a tractor on my bike.
I was clean over the top and knocked myself out.
So the parkkeeper took me into his hut.
I mean, he wouldn't dare do it today, would they?
But the parkkeeper took me into his hut
until he felt I was well enough to get up,
and he wanted me to go home.
But he said, no, I must go to work. I'm on my way to work.
So I pushed my Brent bike to work.
When I got there, they were so concerned about me,
they wanted me to go up to the hospital,
which in those days was St David's Hospital.
So the boss had a Rolls and a chauffeur,
so I had my first ride in a Rolls-Royce,
going to the hospital with my concussion.
And did you have concussion?
Yes, I had concussion.
And this was before the games, was it?
No, that was after.
That was after.
You talked a bit, I'll just ask you about this,
because you talked a bit about this man
who had a dreadful injury and well disappeared.
Were you aware of any other injuries on the factory floor?
No, I don't think I was.
I mean, they had a nurse on site,
and there used to be, I think,
there was a man who once got his hands caught in a machine,
because they used to be after a bit dangerously,
and sometimes worked without a guard down
because the guard made the job difficult.
And there was one man who caught his hands in there.
But apart from that dreadful one where the man disappeared,
I don't recall any more.
There must have been, but there would have been
small and insignificant injuries, I would think.
Do you think the work was dangerous?
It must have been in some instances,
if the man could catch his hand
and if somebody could fall in there.
But my job wasn't dangerous.
So let's go on to the hours and the holidays.
So how many days did you work a week?
Five. And it was nine till five.
Clock in and clock out.
You had to clock in, did you? Yes.
And were there any shifts worked?
Were you aware of that?
No. I don't think even the factory workers worked shifts.
I think there were set hours there.
I would imagine if they had an emergency
or a big order that had to be met,
people would have turned to.
But I think as a general rule it stuck to.
But the men had longer hours.
They started at eight, I think, in the morning,
and we started at nine.
And I think they finished about the same time as us.
So if they did have, I presume they'd work a bit of overtime
if they had an order,
would you ever be asked to work out?
No. Because I just have to make sure that the material
that they needed after hours was available to them.
There. Right.
And did you have any breaks to review working day?
Yes. We had a tea break.
We had a canteen,
but we used to get a tea or coffee and bring it to the office.
And then of course there was a lunch break
and there was a canteen there.
But I didn't.
I didn't have my bike.
It was the top end of Grangetown near town
and I lived in Clive Street, which was not so far away.
So I used to go home on my bike and come back.
How long would it take you on the bike?
About a quarter of an hour each way.
And we had an hour for lunch, so it was enough.
And you always went home, did you?
Usually, yes. Sometimes I went into town,
I did a bit of shopping because it wasn't far.
But it wasn't much of a shopaholic then.
So I didn't do much of that.
You had your mind on greater things.
So you never used the canteen then, did you?
Yes, I did occasionally, but mostly just for coffee.
And I had to get the boss' teas and coffees every day.
And he hated it if I brought him back biscuits with currants in
because he said they could be dead flies.
So were you aware of what kind of food the canteen provided?
Was it like a full kind of cooked?
I don't think there was a lot of selection, but it was cooked.
I think there were probably two selections,
and there certainly wasn't a cold counter.
But those were not long after the war years.
So what about afternoon break? Did you have an afternoon?
Yes, we had an afternoon break.
But we usually just carried on with our work
and had a cup of tea or coffee at our desk.
Whereas we'd stop for ten minutes or so in the morning.
And then we had an hour for lunch.
So did you have an annual holiday allowance with pay then?
Yes, a fortnight was all.
And you could book it in, your own time you could apply.
You put in your holiday hours and I don't think I was ever refused.
Right. Did you ever take more than that?
No, I don't think so.
Was that insufficient?
Probably when we went to the Games I probably did.
I must have done then, because we were there a bit longer.
I should remember that, but I'm afraid I don't.
You said you were paid for your holidays.
Was that just that fortnight?
Yes, well I continued to pay me even though I had my holidays as well as that time for the Games.
I didn't have to take my holiday quota to go to the Games.
They gave me my holidays as well.
And they paid you?
They paid me. They paid me while I was away.
They were a very good company to work for I think.
Because I did have on one occasion a problem with a man I'd met on a train and spoken to
and who found out where I worked and he got to be pestering and an awful nuisance.
Our manager and our managing director got him the sack from his company.
He was quite high up in the business.
So they did care about their staff.
This had happened out of working hours.
It was when I was on one of my train journeys for training and a gentleman just got talking.
The carriages were over the corridor and he'd be sat with people.
It was a long way. I was going right up to changing trains at Manchester and going on in up to Yorkshire.
This man just befriended me I thought and carried my case when I went to change trains.
But in this conversation I told him where I worked and he contacted me and made a nuisance of himself.
But my boss sorted it out.
The director of the company sorted it out, not my immediate boss.
So they did look after their girls.
Do you think you were a kind of feather in their cap then?
I don't know.
Do you think you were special?
Or would they have done that for you?
I think they'd have done it for anyone.
I can't say. When I was in my home environment and when I was in my local environment,
I was a star because I was going to be an Olympian.
But when I was in work I was really just one of the girls.
So I think the treatment I received everyone would have had.
They were very good employees.
Except for the holidays.
That's right. And they took me in when they weren't looking for someone to do anything.
They took me in because I had a need.
So they were a good company.
I don't know whether BSA still exists. I'd like to know.
I'll Google it.
What about bank holidays? Did you have bank holidays?
Yes, bank holidays are off always.
Did you ever go on holiday anywhere else except for your training?
Oh, yes. We always had holidays from a small child.
My parents weren't well off but we'd lived the life of Rhyling.
We had holidays in cottages in West Wales and Vye Valley.
Sometimes we'd travel there on the back of an open-back lorry.
But we'd get there and pitch tents or whatever.
We were always at the beach.
My father taught us to swim when we were very young.
My mother could run like the wind so she used to be dashing up and down, running fast.
I had a very happy, busy, healthy childhood.
So you said your father was a very good swimmer?
Yes, he was.
He used to swim in the Taff River a lot in those days.
They used to have the Taff race every year.
There was a man called...
I've got him in this book.
He always won the Taff swim and he used to train for it by doing it.
My father used to go with him and used to lead all the way but didn't have the money to enter.
He was one of a large family that had neither father nor mother who had both died.
He was the breadwinner from the age of 14.
So there was never the money for him to enter the Taff race.
He used to swim with a man called Rad Milovic.
He used to win it every year.
My father would lead him or could beat him every time but didn't have the money to enter.
Very sad.
What about your mother? Did your mother race?
She could run but there was no athletics in our area that I know of at my mother's time.
She played baseball and she could get around those bases like a hare.
She had a crippled sister who had a club foot who could bat like mad and was a very good backstop.
When it was her sister's turn, her sister would hit the ball and my mother would run for her.
But then she'd have to do her own run as well.
She was very much that way.
She'd had a very hard life and childhood from acute poverty.
Before she left school, she left school at about 13, she was already scrubbing out offices.
She had to take a walk about half an hour to get to it before school and after school.
When she finished school, it was a brush factory.
She said, this is good, I can be a factory girl instead.
She had to do the scrubbing in the morning and the night and the factory work.
She'd come up the hard way.
My dad, as I say, was his father.
That was his father.
He was an engineer on the tugboats in Cardiff Dock.
He dropped it on the boat with a heart attack.
His wife had already died in the flu epidemic after the First World War.
The youngest child was six months when she died.
My father was the oldest boy and there were nine of them altogether.
He was brought home.
They knocked the door and opened the door and they carried him in feet first and laid him on the table.
They walked out and left the children with the dead father.
He was working hard right from the beginning.
In those days, I was in a fortunate time when, if you had skills and a bit of financial help,
you could do it. Nowadays, you get lots of financial help and I'm pleased to see it.
In my mother and father's day, there was no help at all.
Their chances of doing anything in sport were nil really.
Were they both from Cardiff?
Yes, both Grangetown people.
Baseball was a big thing for women, wasn't it?
Oh yes, it was. My mother played for Grippley Mills, although she never worked there.
Her sister worked there, but my mother played for her team.
My mother worked in a brush factory.
They played for Grippley Mills.
That's really interesting. The whole thing about women in factories and sport is very interesting.
So, were there any social activities in the factory that were arranged by the workers?
Not that I can recall. No, I don't think there were any.
On the last working day before Christmas, I think a lot of them used to go to a pub for a celebration,
but I was never one for drinking, so I just used to wish them Merry Christmas and go home.
I wasn't very good at drinking.
Were you a bit younger than most of them as well?
Yes, I was. My parents weren't drinking.
My mother would have a sherry at Christmas or something, but they weren't pub people.
They did nothing against pub people. My grandfather certainly was one, my mother's father was.
It wasn't something that interested me.
There were no outings. I worked with the gas board now and on Wednesday,
going off on the gas board, wrinkly's outing, but there were no outings in this factory now.
It was just work.
So, when did you decide to leave?
When I was pregnant. I got married at 19 and I had my baby at 20.
My husband was at sea. When he went off to sea after the wedding, we didn't know I was pregnant.
When he came back, my son was six weeks old and my husband was not very welcome.
So, you stayed on working then until you got married?
Yes, I worked until I was seven and a half months pregnant.
Then, of course, I stopped and didn't go back.
How did your husband feel about you still working when you were married then?
I was fine because we were hoping to buy a house. We were both going to be saving for a house.
It didn't work out that way for me. It was a bit of a welcome shock eventually.
What did you do afterwards? Did you have more than one child?
Yes, I had two boys. I didn't go back to work until the youngest was 14.
What did you do when you went back to work?
I became a network analyst with the Gas Board.
It changed as time went down and I went on to computers.
What it came down to was that you made sure that if there was a new factory going down at the end of the road,
the lady at the other end could still boil the kettle.
So, they had to put in governors or extra pipe work.
All we did was supply the engineers with all the information and they made the decisions on what to do.
We started off with maps, pens and paper, but eventually it was all done on computers.
I had three computers that could all talk to each other from different parts.
North Wales, West Wales and mine could all talk to each other.
Did you do that for the duration of your life?
Yes, until I retired. From the time my son was 14, the youngest was 14.
Let's think now. He was born in 1958, so that was 1972.
From 1972 until I was 58, which was now. I was born in 1948.
Where does that take us? It's a long time.
When were you born?
1934 and 1958.
I started working there when my son was...
So, is that 1992?
Probably.
1992, 1958 and 34, 1992.
So, you retired about 20 years?
Yes, they were dismantling the gas industry.
Our engineering department was going to Birmingham.
I had a chance to work there if I wanted to, but I only worked part-time anyway.
I was two years off retirement. I was just less than two years off retirement.
That was when retirement was at 60.
I opted for redundancy and went.
So, tell me then about the parallel universe of your sports career.
Tell me what happened in Helsinki.
It was amazing.
From the training bit then, to link it to the factory.
Yes, to link it to the factory.
I had a very good coach, a man called Cecil Guy.
He was an ex-PTI.
After the war, in the wartime he was a PTI in this country.
After the war, several of them were given jobs in what used to be the ARP huts around Cardiff
to set up recreational activities for people who had only known the war and air raids and this sort of thing.
He set up a bowling green. He did bowling, table tennis, football.
He played for Cardiff City Seconds himself in his youth before the war.
He did gymnastics as well. He used to run wist drives and things for people in this little hut.
That's where all my gymnastics started.
Where did you want me to go from here?
I'm sorry, but what does PTI mean?
A physical training instructor.
He was an RAF PTI.
When they were demobbed, some of them managed.
When the men came after the war, they were in jobs for all of them.
He had that job. He was an absolutely brilliant coach.
I used to do all sorts of sports, table tennis, keep fit, country dancing and girl guides.
I did all sorts of things and played the piano quite well actually.
When it came down to it in the end, I knew what I wanted to do.
I'd found my field of expertise really. I was built for it.
I had wonderful support at home.
I had this coach that knew very little about gymnastics before we started this club other than this sort of thing.
He learned a lot and taught me a lot.
It just progressed from there really.
When did you start getting interested in gymnastics?
I used to do something in Ninian Park School when I was a junior.
They used to run a keep fit night.
Mostly it was country dance and things like that.
They also used to do a little bit where you jumped over a box.
There was no springboard or anything.
It was just a coconut mat.
When you landed on it, you disappeared in a cloud of dust.
I started there.
After the war, and during the war as well, they had what they called holidays at home.
Things would go on in the parks for people to have some entertainment.
It was very well thought out actually.
I can remember as a child we used to go and hear bands play and watch different activities going on in the park.
On one occasion I saw this gym coach with some girls and boys.
They were vaulting over a box and tumbling on the mat.
I thought, I'd like to try that.
I went to ask to join and I was told that you had to be 12.
I was 11.
I told him I was 12.
With a blatant lie, I got into the club.
Then I just started from there.
He must have spotted the talent.
I still coach gymnastics now.
We've got another class tonight.
You can pick out.
Usually if they're a bit on the dwarf side, if you're a bit of a midget, you've got a better chance of being a gymnast.
He encouraged me and he was very supportive.
He did a lot of learning himself.
He travelled a lot with me as well, which I think he'd be unlikely to do these days, a man with a little girl.
My parents trusted him implicitly and used to come and visit my parents quite regularly to explain what was planned and what was going on.
I think they were quite happy about that.
That's how it really got going.
When I got to be selected and we went over to the Games, it was so exciting.
I can tell you a funny story. Would you like to hear it?
When we got to go on the plane, we gymnasts were all the midgets on the plane.
One person on the plane was MacDonald Bailey, who was supposed to win the gold medal in the sprints.
He didn't actually. He heard McKendie from Kenya on it.
That's another story, but not a very savoury one.
They wanted to film MacDonald Bailey going up the steps and going to the plane.
I thought it would be interesting if they had these little girls going up at the same time, because he was like 9ft 4cm.
He was enormous and very black. Such a gentleman.
We all had to get off the plane, our team and that.
As we were going up the steps now, we had to wave and it was Pathy News.
The camera was taking it down.
My mother was very worried because no one in our family had ever been up in an aeroplane.
My mother was quite convinced we were going to crash.
I had to tell her. She made me promise that when I got there I would send a telegram.
Don't spend a lot of money. Just put, arrive safely.
I passed out on the plane. I'm a terrible traveller. That's another story.
When I got there, I sent my mother the telegram and it said, arrive safely, see Pathy News.
She must be on Pathy News.
We went to the Capitol Cinema, she and my father.
They used to have two films then and lots of bits going on.
My mother's backside was making bed because it was not coming on.
Eventually, there was cock-a-doodle-doo and this thing.
Going over to the Olympics today, there we were going up the steps.
My mother shot up in the middle of the cinema waving at me and saying, there's Al Gwyn.
My father was saying, sit down woman, sit down.
She embarrassed him no end.
She was so overcome by it, she had to wave back and stand up and shout out to do it.
It was funny.
When we got over there, I'm surprised we did any work at all because we'd had a lot of rationing over here.
There, I can remember sending my mother a card saying, we're allowed two eggs.
That was then heard of. You could actually have two eggs on your plate.
There was no rationing and we ate ourselves silly.
I'm surprised we managed to do any gymnastics because the food was fabulous.
We had a good time over there.
When we got there, we found out that all the work we'd been doing, which had been translated from the French, was incorrect translation.
They used to do set work and voluntary work in those days.
All the set work was wrong.
We had to spend our time getting it right.
How were you selected?
We had trials.
They also had, in those days, the last of the games where the women did a team drill.
They watched to do that as well.
Different ones would take different places and so on.
I was very good at dance.
I think that helped me get into the team as well, was the fact that I was rather good at the team drill.
Some of the girls were a bit on the stiff side, moving.
I top scored for the team.
I wasn't the youngest in the team.
Valerie Mullins was the youngest.
She was three days younger than me and she was from Swansea.
I top scored in the games for our team, but we didn't come anywhere.
How many of you from Wales went?
In that games, we were the majority.
There were three from Swansea.
Susie Davies, Valarie Marians and Margo Morgan.
The first reserve was from Swansea too, but she didn't go.
Then there was myself and Margo Thomas.
Five of us and it was a team of eight.
We were two from Cardiff and three from Swansea in the women's team.
We were five of the eight.
We did really well.
That was a spectacular result then, wasn't it?
Yes, it was indeed.
How did the team do?
Badly.
It was mostly because when you did sets on voluntary,
the set work had been wrongly translated.
Some of them really struggled to do the bar set the new way.
I was very strong and I did quite well on it.
As a team, we sent down.
When we got there, we found that the vault,
we'd been used to a springboard, not like they have today,
but it had a thing across and it had some spring.
When we got there, it was what we would have called a beat board,
which was just a board and then planks going down and it was solid.
You could jump on it, but there was absolutely no spring at all.
Nobody could get over on this hand spring vault.
You had to get to full handstand and spring off it.
That was the set vault because we had more complicated voluntary vaults on that.
Most of the girls couldn't get up.
In those days, they used to vault with the board in quite close.
I thought, if we moved the board back and ran a bit further,
perhaps we could dive and get up there.
Myself and another girl from our team managed to get up and do it.
They used to train in gyms then.
A country would have an hour or two hours, I can't remember the amount of time,
followed by another and another.
Following us on one occasion was the Russian team.
They had a glass door.
They were waiting outside, looking through the glass door.
He came in and asked whether he could film me doing this vault.
They had this sort of cine camera.
I've still got one upstairs.
He had that sort of cine camera.
He took films of me doing it.
Anyway, we didn't see them working all the time.
When it came to the finals day, they had the final stop on each apparatus.
We got there early so we could get a front seat.
The front seat was right on the floor, not as it would be now.
One of the Russian girls won and her vault was very poor.
She got the medal.
He brought her over to me, seeing me sitting in the front.
He took the medal off her and hung it around my neck.
He shook his head and took it back and put it on her and went.
He knew she shouldn't have won it.
What they did in those days, if they didn't want you to win,
they wouldn't knock you off a bit.
They'd knock you off a lot and claim that it must have been a dreadful mistake in there.
I don't think I was even topscorer for vault 14.
I can't remember.
But still an amazing experience.
Amazing. Amazing people from all countries.
We watched the men's as well.
The Indian men took their turbans off and their hair was up in the top,
all tied with a great floppy white bow.
As they were working, it would be coming and done by the yard.
So little things like that.
The Japanese men, they marched past because we always got there early and sat in the front.
As they marched on, they left a waft of perfume behind.
In those days, men didn't wear aftershave in the things, but the Japs did.
We used to watch them go, oh, they smelt lovely, but we thought it was a bit sissy.
There were lots of things like that.
Quite a different world to anything we've lived in.
I just wanted to ask you about any other games.
Olympics and Commonwealth and whatever.
Commonwealth games.
Gymnastics only came into the Commonwealth Games after I retired.
Oh, really? So no gymnastics in Cardiff in 1958?
No, my husband was in it, but he was in it as a highboard diver.
There wasn't any.
For the Olympics, they didn't send a women's team to Australia in 1956.
They had three trials. I won all three trials.
But it was decided that because I was at that time a mother,
it was not right for me to be taken away from my child, so I was denied the chance to go.
They decided that?
They decided that.
We still lived in a big house, in part of a big house that my mother was in,
and my children had two mothers. They wouldn't have missed me.
Anyway, we didn't go. That was one child there.
Then in 1960, I captained a team that went to Rome and topscored there for Britain,
but we didn't come anywhere.
So I did go again, but I've done loads since,
because I've travelled a lot with British teams to world championships,
not to Olympics, but to world championships, European championships and internationals.
There's not a country in Europe I haven't been to, so I've had some wonderful experiences.
The sport's been very good to me. Very good.
Will you be going to the Commonwealth Games this year?
No, it's in Glasgow, but I won't be going.
I don't work high level anymore. I'm interested to watch it, you know.
At the gym club I'm running now, we used to have the main hall in the Pier Pavilion,
and when money was raised to do up the building, which was desperately needed,
we were promised by the council that we could have a church on the top of the hill, which was derelict,
and there was money given to them by a building company to do it up for us,
but they reneged on that. They're now going to sell it off for flats, which is typical of our council, I'm afraid.
So we now rent a factory unit just on the outskirts of Bury, although we're pin-hauled the gymnastics club,
and we've got lots of members there, and as long as we can pay the rent, which is £25,000 a year,
we'll keep going.
We're the only ones that deal with special needs in the area, so the youngsters come to us, you know.
So tell me, when did you retire as a gymnast?
In 1961.
Right, and when did you become a coach?
I was already coaching before I retired, but I didn't qualify as a coach until later,
and I eventually got to an international coaching standard.
Right.
So, you know, it sort of goes to the system club, club, area, national, and so on, when I got to international standard.
So I travelled a lot with British teams.
Right, and you were coaching at the top level then?
Yes.
Yes.
So I had a girl that was in the Olympics.
Right.
Pamela Hopkins she was, Pamela Hardwick she is now, and two girls that have been in the Commonwealth Games in the past.
But to be honest, I don't aim for the dizzy heights anymore because I don't approve of the training programmes for small children that there are.
I don't approve them losing school to train, and I see too many young children retire with overuse injuries.
Children, not adults, children.
And so to get to the standard that you have to get to, you've got to give up a lot and take a lot of risk.
And I'm not prepared for my children to, I call on my children to do that.
If they've got the talent and want that, I'm quite happy to help them move on to someone who will, but I won't be part of it.
I'm an old fashioned biddy, and I don't like the way it goes.
Yes, we've seen that with some people in the Olympics, and tennis and things.
Yes, yes.
Now haven't we, in the last 20 years.
I mean, we've got children now.
When I started gymnastics, my coach didn't take anyone until they were 12, and I wasn't even 12.
But now they're retiring at nine.
I mean, this is appalling.
I shouldn't say this about my own sport, but it is my hobby.
It's one thing I feel very strongly about, very, very strongly.
Tell me about your work now with disabled people.
Well, I designed a programme of work for children with, for school children with disabilities, for schools to take part in.
And I managed to get some sponsorship from Rotary, who fund most of it.
It's still going now, although I haven't been involved with it myself now for four years.
I ran it since, oh, I said 30 odd years I did it, on my kitchen table, until I got to 800 taking part in a year.
So it goes on through schools all throughout Wales.
It's a gradual programme, a progressive programme of work, so that the vault, for instance,
stand on a very small thing and jump off, and that's the vault, until the higher levels actually go over a low box.
So it goes through four ranges of work.
And that still continues.
I was offered a marvellous job in Germany working there.
They offered me a fabulous wage and a flat on it, and a Mercedes, and I didn't want to go to Germany.
And Saudi Arabia used it, because they saw a display of some of this work and asked me to make a copy of the programme,
and I understand they're using it in their schools.
So I'm quite proud of that.
My latest reason to feel proud is that three of my gymnasts,
two with Down syndrome and one autistic, severely autistic, have just gained their coaching awards.
They're qualified as assistant coaches.
They'll never be class responsible, but they've got the dignity of being one.
And they take, on a Thursday we have a beginner's special needs class, and then the advanced ones after,
or the older, sometimes they're not so advanced, they're just getting a bit older.
And they conduct the whole of that class.
They run it under supervision, of course.
We're always there, myself and a couple of others.
But we can just sit and chat, because they just do it brilliantly.
And they've got their coaching awards, so I'm really proud of that.
We already had one Down syndrome boy that had got a coaching award, but he was sort of exceptional.
He still coaches with us now, and he's 38.
He coaches mainstream.
The other three now coach disabled themselves.
So that's nice.
And we've always got someone in the British Special Olympics team, wherever it is.
We've always got someone and they always win. They do really well.
I think, I feel that the people think this is wonderful things for the special people with disabilities.
We've got physical and learning disabilities.
But to me, the ones who benefit the most are the mainstream children, because they train together.
And they get so used to them being there that they're never going to stop in the street,
and their children will never stop in the street and stare at someone who doesn't look quite the same.
And all our social events are together.
We have Christmas parties, we have discos, we have outings, and they're all together.
And it's not unusual for somebody about six years old to come up and say,
Gareth's round the corner and he's crying, and Gareth's 32.
So they never get told anything. They just accept what there is.
They accept them for what they are.
We don't give lessons in how to deal with them.
They just treat them as part of the class, and they get to work it out for themselves.
And I think, for all the work we've done in getting some of the special needs to quite high level of performance,
I think the greatest achievement we have is the acceptance of the mainstreamers with them.
So I'm proud of that.
Can I just ask you one more thing?
Why did you get interested in disability school?
Well, there was not a choice.
We had a running gym club. We used to work in Stanwell School at the time,
when they had a big funding grant to modernise it, it threw us out.
But when we were there, I was asked to go to the YMCA in Cardiff,
which was in the parade, to see some of the gymnasts working.
I was quite impressed, although I felt they were treating them like disabled
and they'd like to be treated like proper people, you know.
Anyway, that's just a personal thing.
But then the girl, it was a man and a husband and wife, and the girl got pregnant.
So they asked us whether we would take them over, take their class over,
for a little while, until after she'd had the baby.
So I said, would I take it over? And I said, no, I can't.
Because I lived in Grangetown and I was training in Penarth, coaching in Penarth,
and they wanted me, and I said, if they can come over to us, we'll put on a special,
we'll move a class back and bring them in in front, and they can come over if they'll be happy with that.
So that was fine. So over they came, and the biggest problem we had was behavioural.
And I thought, well, I'm not putting up with this.
So we got them to tow the party line in no time at all,
and once they did, they had a much better time. They enjoyed it more.
And we had about, I said to the parents, we'll take them for a month,
then we'll have a little discussion about whether you want us to keep them until Angela's had this baby.
And so the parents came in and they said, and I overstepped the mark actually,
because I said, well, one thing we can do is we can make them all socially acceptable.
What I'd received was not socially acceptable, and there was no reason why some of these should behave the way they are,
and they were always going to be, I felt, outcasts.
So some of the parents were a bit shocked at me saying that, but I really felt that that's what we had to offer.
And anyway, they said, yes, they'd like them to stay.
But Angela and her husband never came back, so we just carried on having them,
and we got so involved with them, we shouldn't be without having them like that.
But it wasn't a deliberate thing, it was quite an accident that we took them apart.
Just to ask you one more thing about the factory.
Looking back now, how do you feel about the time you spent working in the factory?
I loved it. Yes, they made me very welcome when I first got there.
I was a very young teenager, I think we were younger in those days,
and they were all adults that I was working with,
so I did feel a bit strange when I first went there, because where there was a lot of girls, they weren't there.
But they were happy days, they were very kind to me, they were appreciative of the work I did.
I felt that the men in the factory treated me nicely, it was good, I enjoyed it.
I only left because I had a baby, and in those days, at least I was of the opinion that if you had a baby you became a man.
That was your first priority.
Can I just ask you about Grangetown as well?
Was there an athletic club?
No, it was an ARP hut.
There was one by Ninian Park School, and there was one down on what they called the Marl, which was down Ferry Road.
Wasn't there something called the Grange Ladies?
Grange Ladies Gymnastic Club was what I was part of. That's what I belonged to.
So that's what I wanted to ask you about. When did that start?
That was the display that I saw in the park.
They were Grange Ladies. They also ran a boys' team as well.
They had more girls than boys, but the boys mostly did the football.
That was how I came to join because I'd seen them in the park.
This will be the school again.
